poem:
Title: 'A Farce in Tinseltown'

In the masquerade of cinema, gilded glitter lies,
Two hearts synchronized in performance, a trick of the spyglass eyes.
An Oscar's lustrous apogee, in familial ties does dwell,
Yet, beneath the marquee's clamor, an empty echo knell.
And Barbie dances through it all, a doll lost in the game,
Whilst silent Gosling mutters, despising plastic fame.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Power couples: how Hollywood’s big name Oscar contenders balance life and work The Academy award nominations on Tuesday contained, among the plethora of announcements, intriguing evidence of the strength of familial connections underpinning major Oscar bids, with a number of the 10 films nominated for best picture containing both members of high profile relationships, working together on the same film. Barbie, the doll-inspired blockbuster that, to the chagrin of many including Ryan Gosling, appeared to". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
